key_title: Key to the species of Pultenaea

source.author: Corrick, M.G.
source.title: Pultenaea
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Corrick, M.G. (1996). Pultenaea. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaf-blade with margin recurved or revolute (leaves occasionally concave or V-shaped in section), if margin flat then leaf darker on upper surface
Leaf-blade with margin incurved or involute, if margin flat then leaf darker on lower surface
Flowers terminal, forming a condensed raceme or head-like cluster (occasionally solitary), sessile or shortly pedicellate; shrubs not mat-forming, mostly more or less erect
Flowers 1 per leaf axil (rarely 2) on pedicels usually much longer than leaves; shrubs mat-forming to decumbent
Flowers solitary, rarely 2 together at tips of branches
Flowers clustered towards tips of branches or in terminal heads of 3 or more
Inflorescence lacking bracts, but persistent, slightly enlarged stipules present at base of pedicels
Inflorescence surrounded by bracts, bracts persistent or partially or totally deciduous at or before anthesis
Stipules straw-coloured, prominently fringed with cilia, almost obscuring the stem
Stipules dark brown, glabrous or sparsely hairy, not obscuring stem
Leaves lanceolate to elliptic, base rounded or obtuse; flowers in a discrete terminal head-like cluster
Leaves linear to obovate, base attenuate or cuneate; flowers in small terminal or subterminal clusters, or solitary
Bracts deciduous (slightly enlarged stipules may persist at base of pedicels)
Bracts persistent
Leaf-apex pungent
Leaf-apex obtuse, emarginate, or acute but not pungent
Leaf-blade narrowly elliptic to linear, tapering gradually to a pungent point
Leaf-blade cuneate to oblanceolate, terminating abruptly in a pungent mucro
Flowers 5–6 mm long, standard 4–6 mm wide
Flowers at least 7–10 mm long, standard up to 12 mm wide
Leaf upper surface scabrous, with tubercle-based hairs, rarely glabrous but not smooth; lower surface with loose, often rusty hairs; margin recurved
Leaves with both surfaces glabrous; margin fiat, thickened or slightly recurved
Most leaves more than 3 times as long as wide and more than 10 mm long; apex very obtuse, usually indented; margin thin; rigidly branched shrub of granite hills of north-east
Most leaves less than 3 times as long as wide (usually c. twice) and less than 10 mm long; apex with short, obliquely recurved mucro; margin thick; slender plant of wet lowlands in southern Victoria
Lower leaf surface with spreading hairs; calyx tube with dense, spreading hairs
Lower leaf surface with appressed hairs; calyx with appressed, silky hairs
Flowers 5–8 mm long; standard 3–6 mm wide
Flowers (9–) 10–12 mm long; standard more than 7 mm wide
Flowers 7–8 mm long; standard 5–6 m wide; stipules 1–1.5 mm long, free, or united at base only
Flowers 5–6 mm long; standard 3–4 mm wide; stipules 3–7 mm long, united for most of their length
Stipules 1.5–2 mm long, up to one-quarter as long as leaf
Stipules 3–7 mm long, up to one-third as long as leaf
Leaves mostly less than 4 mm wide; apex tapering gradually, acute
Leaves mostly more than 4 mm wide; apex obtuse with a weak, recurved mucro
Shrubs mat-forming, variously hairy with antrorse hairs
Shrubs not mat-forming, loosely procumbent or decumbent; stem hairs spreading to somewhat retrorse in 2 classes c. 0.1 mm and 0.5 mm long
Ovary pubescent to the base
Ovary glabrous or with hairs only at summit
Leaves in whorls of 3
Leaves alternate
Bracteoles trifid, divided at or above middle; central lobe narrow, linear, outer lobes broad, brown and conspicuous
Bracteoles entire or, if trifid, then divided below middle with central lobe often leaf-like and outer lobes narrow and inconspicuous
Leaf-apex with long, weak, recurved point; stipules 4–5 mm long, strongly recurved; lower stems leafless with prominent stipular scars; standard c. 10 mm long and wide
Leaf-apex blunt; stipules 2–3 mm long, not recurved; lower stems usually leafy; standard c. 10 mm long, 7 mm wide
Leaves tapering to a point, usually pungent, concave or V-shaped in section and recurved from stem, venation usually palmate (apparent on lower surface)
Leaves blunt; venation not palmate
Leaves l-4 (–5) mm long, 0.5–3 mm wide, less than twice as long as wide
Leaves 5–15 mm long, 1–5 mm wide, more than twice as long as wide
Bracteoles lanceolate or linear, longer than calyx tube
Bracteoles broadly ovate, shorter than calyx tube
Leaves spreading; blade more or less flat with incurved margin; flowers deep orange and brick red; stems and usually whole plant hairy (glabrous plants occur in Rush worth area)
Leaves more or less erect, terete; flowers pure yellow, stems and usually whole plant glabrous (plants with hairy leaves occur in Kinglake area)
Leaves opposite or in whorls of 3
Leaves alternate
Leaves in whorls of 3, glabrous; moist to wet areas of alpine and subalpine areas
Leaves opposite, underside with sparse, pale, appressed hairs
Diffuse subshrub; leaf margins incurved; endemic in Grampians
Shrub; leaf margins flat to slightly incurved
Bracteoles variously 3-lobed (outer lobes often obscure)
Bracteoles entire
Lateral lobes of bracteoles conspicuous, brown, non-resinous and papery, and as wide or wider than central lobe
Lateral lobes of bracteoles usually inconspicuous, pale and not wider than central lobe, or, if wider than central lobe then dark and resinous
Stipules pale, united almost to the tips, overlapping and obscuring stem; leaves mucronate, rigid, glabrous except when very young; rare shrub of Little Desert
Stipules dark, united only at the base
Leaves and stems with spreading hairs; uncommon erect shrub of western forests
Leaves and stems glabrous; trailing or weakly erect undershrub, widespread in damp situations
Leaves softly hairy, usually more than 8 mm long
Leaves glabrous or sparsely hairy only when young, usually less than 8 mm long
Stem hairs not appressed, centre lobe of bracteole shorter than calyx (calyx usually glabrous)
Stem hairs appressed, silky, centre lobe of bracteole as long or slightly longer than calyx
Leaf-apex pungent, aristate or acicular
Leaf-apex obtuse or acute but not pungent (a fragile, bristle-like mucro, often deciduous with age, may be present)
Underside of leaves with 3–5 prominent longitudinal veins
Underside of leaves not obviously veined or with 1 prominent central vein
Flowers in terminal head-like clusters of more than 3 flowers, stipules united only at the base, strongly recurved; underside of mature leaves glabrous; restricted to Grampians
Flowers single, or rarely, 2 together terminating short lateral shoots; stipules united for most of their length, not recurved; underside of leaf with silky, appressed hairs
Bracteoles linear, ovate or lanceolate, usually hairy at least on midrib
Bracteoles broadly ovate, resinous and shining, hairs if present restricted to a basal tuft
Calyx and young stems and leaves with appressed silvery hairs, mature leaves glabrous; leaves terete; weak trailing subshrub of alpine herbfields and Snow-gum woodlands
Calyx, stems and leaves variously hairy but not as above, if ever with appressed silky hairs then leaves flat; ± erect, woody shrubs
Leaves linear-terete or ovate, often cordate, surfaces usually concolorous
Leaves elliptic to narrowly obovate, widest above the middle, more or less flat, upper surface green, clearly visible, lower surface reddish-brown and much darker than upper surface
Bracteoles much longer than calyx tube, ovate, tapering abruptly into long, slender acute tip; stipules densely fringed with woolly hairs
Bracteoles usually shorter than calyx tube, lanceolate, tapering into short, acute tips; stipules glabrous to pubescent, but never woolly
Calyx glabrous or with spreading hairs; leaves flat or concave, apex with distinct point
Calyx with silky appressed hairs; leaves flat, apex with minute point
Flowers sessile or on pedicels less than 2 mm long
Flowers on pedicels more than 2 mm long
Leaves more or less flat with inrolled margin; bracteoles longer than calyx tube and enveloping it; granite hills in north-east
Leaves terete; bracteoles c. half as long as calyx tube; restricted to northern Grampians
Leaves wider than long, almost orbicular, flowers in umbel-like clusters on pedicels far exceeding leaves
Leaves longer than wide, flowers sessile or on pedicels only slightly exceeding the leaves
Flowers terminal, solitary or up to 3 in a tight or loose cluster
Flowers axillary or in terminal head-like clusters of more than 3 flowers

Flowers in loose terminal clusters of fewer than 4 flowers, sessile, often hidden among subtending leaves; bracteoles lanceolate, densely hairy, usually longer than calyx; rigid, densely hairy coastal shrubs
Flowers solitary or 2 together (rarely 3) in a tight terminal cluster, bracteoles not longer than calyx
Leaves strongly reflexed, 3 parallel veins obscure, usually visible on underside; dry forests west of Melbourne, uncommon
Leaves not reflexed
Calyx-lobes broad, ovate to deltoid, not longer than calyx tube; erect, usually very floriferous shrub of western near-coastal areas
Calyx-lobes lanceolate or long-acuminate, as long as or longer than calyx tube
Bracteoles broadly ovate, more or less enveloping calyx; bracts and bracteoles rounded on back and without prominent midrib; stipules c. 1 mm long, dark brown; chiefly dry inland forests
Bracteoles ovate to oblong, not enveloping calyx; stipules 2–3 mm long, light brown; chiefly coastal dunes, also on calcareous soils in the west
Flowers in tight head-like clusters
Flowers axillary
Flowers rose-pink; higher parts of eastern Grampians
Flowers yellow or orange
Leaves linear, ovate, elliptic or narrowly obovate, more than 4 times as long as wide, upper surface hidden or partially visible; widespread very variable shrub
Leaves obovate, usually much less than 4 times as long as wide
Leaves more or less conduplicate and recurved, 3–5 (–9) mm long, 1–3 mm wide; rigid divaricate shrub of dry forests, often in auriferous areas
Leaves more or less flat, not recurved, 6–8 mm long, 2.5–3 mm wide; rare (probably extinct) plant of Victoria Range, Grampians
Stipules ovate, boat-shaped, free to the base and standing away from the stem; plant highly aromatic, often with a yellow, waxy exudation particularly on the calyx; uncommon shrub of Western Victoria
Stipules lanceolate, united in the lower half, tips slender, recurved; occasionally resinous and/or sweetly scented; widespread very variable shrub
